name: Emma
comment info: The team of nutritionists consulted for this need to widen their own diet. Why is this graph missing beans, lentils, and grains? Man cannot live on bread alone.

name: Carley J
comment info: This is the story of Nutritionist 08, Emily.  Emily was a food nutritionist when she got selected as the 8th expert to rate the healthiness of foods for the New York Times.  Emily was very new to the job, so she made some bad choices, like rating steak as less healthy than wine (I think Emily drank too much wine herself).  She was soon fired by New York Times because she was not professional enough, but before she was fired she used wine to convince the other seven nutritionists to follow her decisions. So, as you look at this graph again, you’ll understand why the nutritionist ratings are not accurate.

replies.comment info:
HI, @Scarlett Cortes --

You say that "many Americans think frozen yogurt is healthier than it really is."  What percentage of nutritionists think frozen yogurt is healthy?  Maybe both the public and nutritionists are not really sure if frozen yogurt is healthy.

How about pork chops and cheddar cheese?  What is the consensus?

name: John S.
comment info:
I notice foods I would consider similarly (un)healthy far from each other on the graph. I wonder if anyone else questions the nutritionists' specific rankings. I believe in science that villifies fructose or hydrogenated fats but I don't see the macro balances or ingredient composition of the foods sorted or sortable by healthfulness on the scatterplot. This relates to how difficult it is to decide healthfulness of a single food item in isolation from the total diet it is part of. 

Is an avocado always healthy? Not if your diet is already high in fat and calories. Is a protein shake always unhealthy? Not if it represents all your added sugar consumption for the day. Is a steak always healthier than a hamburger? Well, that depends on whether you need carbs in your diet.

A headline for this graph could be: a "confusing conflation of foods with diets"

name: Bayley
comment info: I notice that this graph compares how healthy various foods are perceived to be by nutritionists versus the American public. Foods like quinoa, kale, and apples are seen as healthy by both groups, while others like granola and coconut oil are seen as healthy by many Americans but not as much by nutritionists. However, sushi, wine, and popcorn are rated more highly by nutritionists than by the public. I wonder what specific criteria nutritionists used to judge healthiness. Could it be based on nutrients, sugar content, fat, or something else? This relates to me and my community because this graph highlights a common disconnect between expert advice and public belief. In my community, there could be a lot of misinformation about what’s considered “healthy”. A title for this graph could be, "Food Confusion: What Nutritionists Know That Americans Miss About ‘Healthy’ Foods".

name: Moderator Greg
comment info:
Thanks to all the students who responded.   Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received:  “When Experts and Eaters Disagree: What We Think Is Healthy vs. What Actually Is” by Lily of Academy of Saint Elizabeth in Convent Station, N.J. and “Taste vs. Truth: A Data-Driven Bite of America’s Diet Beliefs” by Daniel of Perth Amboy High School, N.J.

 

Please return on Friday when we will reveal the free link to the article, a summary of the article, additional questions, shout outs for some of the best headlines for the graphs and Stat Nuggets -- definitions of words that relate to the graph and where you can find them in the graph.

 

This is the last graph of this school year.  We welcome you back in early September when we will continue to ask you “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  Wonder what the graph will be.

 

Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston, who had popcorn for lunch (Oops.  Is that healthy?) and Greg Yarnall of Convent Station, N.J. who wants to thank the venerable Moderator Sharon for her 8 years of care and guidance for the WGOITG feature. Moderator Sharon has become an icon in my classroom and we'll certainly miss her wisdom and wit in September!

replies.comment info:

name: Lily AOSE
comment info:
This graph shows how nutritionists and the general American public view the healthiness of different foods. The higher a food appears, the healthier nutritionists think it is; the farther right it is, the more the public agrees. Foods on the diagonal line represent agreement between both groups, especially for fruits, vegetables, and lean meats like turkey and chicken. However, there are some clear disagreements—for example, some foods that nutritionists rate as healthy are not viewed that way by the public, and vice versa. This makes me wonder how much public opinion is influenced by marketing, cultural habits, or misinformation. In my community, I’ve noticed that people often choose foods they think are healthy based on labels or trends, even if those choices don't align with expert recommendations. This gap in understanding could impact long-term health and shows how important it is to improve access to accurate nutrition information.

Headline: When Experts and Eaters Disagree: What We Think Is Healthy vs. What Actually Is

replies.comment info:
Good afternoon, @Lily AOSE --

Regarding your first two sentences, I want to make sure you understand what this graph shows.  It’s not how healthy a food is but rather ….  

On the other hand, if we were to ask the public and nutritionists to order the foods by nutritional value, what would that graph look like?  (To do this, maybe you would want to cut the list down to a more manageable number like a dozen foods.)  I wonder if this graph would look similar to the featured graph.

name: Ciara AOSE
comment info:
This scatter plot compares what nutritionists and Americans deem healthy regarding food. I first noticed that Americans generally agree with nutritionists on what foods are healthy. Something else I noticed was that the foods rated the healthiest are typically high in protein. I also noticed that Americans think granola is healthy, while nutritionists do not. Why is that? I also wonder why Kind Bars and granola bars are not marked as the same. This relates to me and my community because it is essential to understand what foods are healthy and what foods are not. From this graph, it is clear that most Americans understand what foods are better for them.

Headline: Nutritional value discrepancies.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Ciara AOSE --

You’ve got the challenge!  

Study the nutrition labels on Kind bars. How many different kinds?  (“A joke and I did not know it.”)  And, granola.  How many different kinds?  (Not a joke.)  Figure out a way to compare them.  Calories?  Protein?  Sugar?  Etc.  

Love to know what you find out.

name: Adam
comment info:
The graph hard to read clearly. Are readers to assume the point is centered in the middle of the item? This works for circular items (hummus, granola) or square items (whole wheat bread). But much tougher for oblong or rectangular shapes.  How do nutritionists rate beer? at the bottom of the bottle (20%), the midpoint (25%), or the top (30%)? Same problem for American's assessment of butter (30-40% range).

My understanding is that many Americans have rather poor diets. This graph suggests that (at least in 2016), they mostly agreed with nutritionists about what they SHOULD be eating. The trick is to get them to actually eat better.

Interesting items are those further from the 1-1 line. Assuming nutritionists are correct, Americans see some items incorrectly as healthy (granola, slimfast, orange juice) and others are less healthy (popcorn, sushi, tofu, shrimp) than they might be. 

I'm not sure that nutritionists would rate wine so highly today -- lot of discussion recently that any amount of alcohol is bad for you. They still might rank beer > diet soda > regular soda, but all are pretty unhealthy.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Adam --

Though a scatter plot with points (dots) is easier to read, aren’t the photos of foods quicker to read and more fun?    Also, a drawing gives more of an impression that these points are not exact.  They have some margin of error.

On Friday, we will reveal the free link to the article which includes this graph.  There, you will find the percentages for 30 of the 52 foods.  This should make you more comfortable with the values.  58 percent of the foods will have statistics good enough for an audit.

I like your ranking of beverages.  Where would milk be in your inequality?  How about orange juice, Gatorade and water?

replies.name: H
replies.comment info: @Adam, I like how you discussed Americans' overall diet. It is interesting to see what people consider healthy versus what is actually healthy. It could be considerably more beneficial for people to conceptualize the overall nutritional value of these foods instead of eating things that they think taste good.

name: Katie AOSE
comment info: This graph displays how nutritionists and Americans rate how healthy different foods are. The higher up a food is, the more nutritionists think it’s healthy; the farther right it is, the more the public agrees. Foods on the diagonal line mean both groups agree. They mostly agree that fruits, veggies, and chicken are healthy and that soda and fries aren’t. I notice that there are big differences like how nutritionists rate things like tofu and quinoa as healthy, but the public doesn’t as much. Meanwhile, people think granola bars and coconut oil are super healthy, but nutritionists disagree. This makes me wonder how food marketing might be tricking Americans. As an American, it makes me realize I should double-check what I think is healthy. Headline: “Who Really Knows What’s Healthy?”

name: Addison AOSE
comment info:
In this graph, I noticed only around 10 foods on the line. This means there are only 10 foods in this group that nutritionists and people agree are healthy/unhealthy. I also see that all foods nutritionists and people rate as healthy were whole foods. On the contrary, the ones that both groups agreed were unhealthy were processed. Another thing I recognized is that some foods, like kind bars and diet sodas, are marked as health/healthier foods; however, in reality, they are not. I am curious what percentage of people consume the foods they deem unhealthy while knowing they are unhealthy. I also wonder how that percentage compares to the amount of healthy food people consume. I also wonder what role social media and the media in general play in people's perception of how healthy or unhealthy certain foods are. This applies to me because I enjoy fueling my body with healthy, whole foods, but I also love indulging in foods like ice cream and burgers! This chart allows me to recognize healthy food choices and makes me more aware of what exactly is going into my body.

Title: Nutrition In America: whats real and whats fake?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Addison AOSE --

Take another look at Kind bars.  Yes, we love them, but what percentage of the public and nutritionists say they are healthy?  Is social media playing a role in labeling Kind bars as healthy?

name: Scarlett
comment info: I notice that this graph is comparing foods based on if they are healthy or not, ranked by nutritionists and the American people. I see that lots of the sugary foods and drinks are commonly named unhealthy by both nutritionists and by Americans, such as chocolate chip cookies and a can of coke. This did not surprise me because cookies and soda are known to be sugary, unhealthy food/drink choices.  I also noticed that more than half of nutritionists ranked popcorn and wine as healthy, which I found pretty surprising because popcorn is a snacking food commonly found in movie theaters, which I would not think to be that healthy. Wine is an alcoholic beverage which I would think would be pretty neutrally ranked, but about 70% of nutritionists said it was healthy. I wonder why wine is considered healthy by nutritionists if it is known to negatively affect our liver. I also wonder why kind bars are low on the chart (roughly only 30% of nutritionists and Americans saying it is a healthy food), if it is just filled with nuts, and nuts are ranked at the highest of the chart by both Americans and nutritionists. This relates to me and my community because as an American citizen, many of the food options I am surrounded by are unhealthy and filled with lots of sugar. Seeing this chart makes me rethink my food choices, and see what foods may be a better option to consume.                               Catchy Headline: Across the grid: Nutritionists vs American's perspectives on food items

comment info:

3. How does this relate to me and my community?

“NutritionMania; The Discrepancy of The Perceived Healthiness of Foods between average Americans and American Nutritionists”

name: Jackie AOSE
comment info:
7. This graph illustrates how Americans’ beliefs about what foods are healthy align with the expert opinions of nutritionists. Many foods that the public considers unhealthy such as cookies, soda, and fries are also deemed unhealthy by nutritionists. These kinds of foods are known to contain high amounts of sugar, fat, and salt, explaining their place on this graph. This is true for the other side of the spectrum too, with Americans and nutritionists agreeing that fruits, vegetables, oatmeal, and almonds are beneficial for diets. Cookies, hamburgers, baked potatoes, peanut butter, turkey, carrots, and apples have about the same rating from both sides. However, there are some areas where public opinion strays from expert opinion. An example of this is granola bars, with 70% of Americans seeing them as healthy while only 30% of nutritionists think the same. 
6. I wonder if there is disagreement among nutritionists on what foods are healthy or not. What makes some meats, like chicken, very healthy while steak is considered less healthy. What food ingredients do nutritionists recommend you avoid?
5. This relates to me because I am trying to eat foods that are better for my health. This graph can help me determine the difference between what society thinks of as healthy vs. what is actually healthy. In this way, I can craft a diet that is best for me.
4. Nutritious or Fictitious? How Popular and Expert Belief Compare

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Jackie AOSE --

You write, “I wonder if there is disagreement among nutritionists on what foods are healthy or not.”  The answer is right in the graph.  What do you notice?  Regarding this group of foods, I wonder why they disagree?  What do you hypothesize?

In the article, there is a link at the end of the article to a prior New York Times story on “common-sense” rules on what to eat.  Not a bad list.

2. Why is there a line increasing in the middle?  How come wine is healthy if it can also hurt our liver? How is diet soda not so healthy and nutritious for us?

3. This relates to me and my community that there's people out there who only eat junk foods and gain so much weight without realizing. Also there are some healthy foods for us but wine is like a make or break it type of drink because we can over drink.

4. Are these food very healthy for us? America are in danger!!

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Ella Gumbs The line in the middle is the line of best fit. This line usually serves as a representation of how 2 variables best connect to each other.

replies.comment info:
@Ella Gumbs

Come back on Friday to find out even more!

name: Victoria AOSE
comment info:
Headline: Nutritionists vs. Americans: Perception of Health in Foods 
I notice that a good amount of the foods are rated the same by nutritionists and the public. However, there are a few that seem to be rated higher in terms of healthiness by the public than by nutritionists. In particular, about 75% of the American public says that granola bars are healthy. However, only about 25% of nutritionists say granola bars are healthy. There is a similar gap between coconut oil and frozen yogurt. I also agree with the majority of the American public, who rated things like frozen yogurt and granola bars as healthy. I wonder why nutritionists think otherwise. I think this graph is trying to show that certain foods are perceived by the public as healthy when actually they are not. I also think the graph shows the healthiness of whole foods. Because the items rated the highest by nutritionists and the public are whole foods, meaning they are unprocessed. I also think its important to note that a lot of foods have both healthy and unhealthy components. So, it is difficult to classify one as completely unhealthy or healthy, and this generalization could impact the graph results. This graph relates to my community and me because my mom is an “almond mom,” which means she influences our family to eat healthy and avoid processed food. This graph will help my family and people, in general, to be aware of misconceptions about food health and follow nutritionists' advice.

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Victoria AOSE --

“I also think it's important to note that a lot of foods have both healthy and unhealthy components. So, it is difficult to classify one as completely unhealthy or healthy, and this generalization could impact the graph results.”  What are examples of these foods from the foods shown in the graph?  What characteristics do these foods have?

I learned a new word(s) – almond mom.  I looked it up and Merriam-Webster dictionary defines an almond mom as “a mother who imposes unhealthy eating habits and harmful expectations about weight and body image onto her children, especially daughters.”  Wow!  

In the article, there is a link at the end of the article to a prior New York Times story on “common-sense” rules on what to eat.  Not a bad list.  Wonder what you and your mom think of these recommendations.

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Victoria AOSE You made a good finding regarding the granola bars, and what percent of nutritionists and Americans consider them healthy. It is interesting to see how average American people see food as healthy or unhealthy.

name: Kelsey
comment info: In this graph I noticed that it is comapring how people and nutritionalist view certain foods on a scale of how healthy they view it. People and nutritionists were able to agree easily on the two extremes of this graph, very healthy and very not healthy. I noticed that there are many misconceptions between what people view as an unhealthy food and what nutritionists view as unhealthy. I wonder if this graph can shed light on the fact that not all products marketed as healthy are actually so? I also wonder if social media plays a role in these misconceptions about certain foods? This relates to my community because everyone always tries to eat healthier, but this graph shows that there are many discrepencies about what is actually a healthy food. It is impossible for people to eat "better" if they don't understand what better means. I would title this graph: Food Fact or Fiction?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Kelsey --

“In this graph I noticed that it is comparing how people and nutritionists view certain foods on a scale of how healthy they view it.”  Does this graph show how healthy foods are or something else?  (Hint:  Re-read the headline, the labels on the axes and the paragraphs below the graph.) 

What foods do you think social media shows as healthy but nutritionists think are not healthy?  What is practical to do about this discrepancy?

name: SophiaAOSE
comment info:
This graph compares how healthy Americans see certain foods versus how healthy nutritionists have found food to be. I noticed that foods with higher sugar or carb levels were found to be less healthy and foods with fiber or greens were found to be more healthy by nutritionists. For the most part, it was relatively similar between what nutritionists say is healthy and what the general public thinks. However, there were some exceptions like granola bars that the public thought was healthy, but nutritionists said actually wasn't. I wonder what makes certain foods healthier than others in the eyes of nutritionists. This affects my community because these are foods that we eat everyday and it turns out that we might not be eating as healthy as we think we are. 
Headline: Food, Food, Food

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's live moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  Today’s graph is about how the public and nutritionists regard if 52 foods are healthy to eat.  

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online for the four questions.  If you include a claim, please back it up with evidence that supports your claim.  By Friday morning, we’ll give shout outs for some of the catchiest headlines and more.  There is no accompanying article, just the graph from the print version of the New York Times.

You can get a link to your response to share with your teacher and classmates by clicking the response box below your response “Email me when my comment is published.”  

This is the last graph of this school year and my last graph for the New York Times Learning Network feature “What’s Going On in This graph?”  After eight years and more than 200 graphs, it’s time to move on.  The feature will continue in early September when we will ask you “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  Wonder what the first graph will be.

name: Katie
comment info: This graph displays a comparison between regular individuals' rating of food health versus nutritionalists' rating of food health. In most cases, foods with higher sugar levels were found to be less healthy in comparison to more nutritious foods such as fruits. Popcorn, in this case, is in the middle. I wonder what the process of ranking these foods was. For example, did they simply do it from background knowledge, or did they dive into detail into the different components of each food?

replies.comment info:
HI, @Katie --

You “wonder what the process of ranking these foods was.”  The paragraphs below the graph explain how the data was obtained.  

And, be careful, the foods are not ranked (from healthiest to least health).  Are the foods ranked (1st, 2nd, 3rd,…) or is the data something else?  Take another look and share with us what you discovered.

name: Conner AP Lang
comment info: I noticed that for a lot of foods that people think are "healthy" such as granola, really aren't that healthy. Even Slimfast, which is a large competitor in weight loss shakes, is considered unhealthy by experts. I wonder why there are fads around foods that aren't good for you. As someone who has tried to lose weight, foods such as granola always get suggested. However, based on this graph, it really isn't that good for you. A headline I would put on this would be "Nutrition or Fad Food?"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Conner AP Lang --

Welcome Conner from AP Lang.  When is your AP Lang exam?  Might you choose to explain the graphs in one of your open response essays?  

You bring up many good points.  Let's focus on your headline -- "Nutrition or Fad Food?"  Can food be divided into two mutually exclusive categories, as you have in your headline?  That is, a food is either nutritious or a fad food.  How about a counter example.  What foods are both nutritious and a fad food?   Which foods are neither?  How about rephrasing your headline?

replies.name: V
replies.comment info: @Conner AP Lang I also wonder why there are some unhealthy food trends that are glorified in the media.

replies.name: J
replies.comment info: @Conner AP Lang what do you think causes misconceptions about what foods are healthy or not?

name: CIkan
comment info:

How does this relate to you and your community? It relates to my community and I because we consume these foods on the daily, so understanding the content that we put in our bodies is extremely important.

Nutritionists outline a graph ranking foods from least to most healthiest.

However, something like a SlimFast shake probably has no sugar but is a lot more unhealthy because it's severely processed.

replies.comment info:
Hi, @AP Lang student --

You write “a "healthy" scale” and “food healthiness.”  What do you mean by these descriptions of the foods?  Does the graph display how healthy a food is or something else?

Foods are considered less healthy if they have a lot of sugar, fat or salt.  Foods that have fat include meat and cheeses.  Where do you see them on the graph?  Interpret what the graph shows about these foods.  (There’s a surprise here.)

Here's to you and your class doing very well on the AP Lang exam next week!  Hope you respond with the graphs!

name: Penelope G.
comment info:
What do you notice?
I notice the Y-axis shows the percent of nutritionists saying a food is healthy, while the X-axis shows the percent of Americans saying the food is healthy. replies.name: V
replies.comment info: @Penelope G. I love your comment! I was also wondering about how wine and popcorn could be considered healthier than a granola bar. I believe that most granola bars are highly processed, while many wines are made from simple and natural ingredients. Furthermore, popcorn is made of one natural ingredient as long as no butter or salt is added. I think there is a big misconception that foods have to be low in calories, carbs, and sugar to be healthy. However, I believe that whole foods and unprocessed items are generally more important for overall health than simply focusing on low calories, carbs, and sugar.

name: Layla Giron
comment info: Of all the foods mentioned, quinoa is one of the healthiest. It is a whole grain rich in vegetable protein, fiber, vitamins and minerals. Unlike pizza, frozen yogurt or pork chops, quinoa has no saturated fat or added sugars. It is also easy to digest and good for the heart.

name: Johan P3
comment info:
1)This chart shows how nutritionists and the general public differ in their views on which foods are healthy. There’s strong agreement on items like fruits, vegetables, and chicken, while big disagreements appear with foods like granola bars, coconut oil, and frozen yogurt. Nutritionists are more skeptical of some trendy "health" foods, while Americans often misjudge the health value of processed or high-fat items.
2)One thing I wonder is why so many Americans believe granola bars are healthy, despite nutritionists rating them much lower?
3)As a high school student living in New Jersey, this chart makes me think about how easy it is to get confused about what’s actually healthy, especially with so many snack options at stores like Wawa or QuickCheck. A lot of people around here grab things like granola bars or coconut oil because they seem healthy, but nutritionists don’t always agree.
4)“Nutritionists vs. America: The Food Fight You Didn’t Know About.”

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @Johan P3 I agree with everything you said about it realting to your community. It relates to mine too and I think it is very interesting to consider.

name: Dialeski Per 3
comment info:

I've also realized that foods that are supposed to be marketed as healthy are barely actually considered healthy by nutritionists, and even some Americans, such as the SlimFast Shake, Kind bar, and diet soda. 
2. I wonder why nutritionists don't consider granola bars, granola, and coconut oil as healthy as I thought they would. How is popcorn greater in health than those foods I just listed? 
3. This relates to my community and I because I feel as if a lot of foods that are considered healthy to us aren't actually healthy, as said by nutritionists. This whole time I believed coconut oil and granola bars were extremely healthy, but it's barely high up in the list. 
HEADLINE- "Perception vs Reality: Nutritionists Combat the American Beliefs of Healthy Foods"

I wonder how much of our perception of "healthy" food is shaped by marketing rather than actual nutritional value. 

3) How does this relate to you and your community?
This relates to me and my community because many people make food choices based on convenience and advertising rather than their actual nutritional facts. In my instance, some people may choose a quickcheck sub over Wendy's, but in reality they're equally as unhealthy. 

4) What’s going on in this graph?
"Healthy or Hyped? What Americans Think vs What Nutritionists Know"

replies.name: J

replies.name: N
replies.comment info: @Ricardo Castillo I agree with your questions and thoughts this was a good interpretation of the graph.

name: Daniel Vasquez
comment info:
Observations - In this graph, 2,000 voters and 672 nutritionists went on to rate the healthiness of 52 foods. Junk foods (Sodas, Pizza, Fries, Ice Cream, Bacon, Beer) were generally considered unhealthy by both voters and nutritionists, though foods like the SlimFast Shake, Coconut Oil & Granola Bars didn’t have as much common ground, with less nutritionists deeming it healthy compared to voters. The opposite happens with foods such as Sushi, Quinoa, and Hummus. Whole foods like Fruits & Vegetables are deemed by both parties to be among the healthiest, while Pork Chops, Whole Milk, and Steak stay in the center, ranging from 50 to 60% for both sides.

Questions - Why do nutritionists rate foods like Granola bars and SlimFast shakes as less healthy than the other voters? What contributes to the gap in perception between nutritionists and everyday voters? I also wonder how much increased nutritional education would narrow the divide between public opinion and the nutritionist consensus.

Relation to Community - In NJ, where food awareness could vary by region, it would be important to know what really is healthy. If there is rising interest in diet and fitness in highly populated areas, the current divide in understanding would reflect how much misinformation really is present. Instead of settling on just choosing the right foods, people should come together to understand *why* they are the right foods.

Headline - Taste vs. Truth: A Data-Driven Bite of America’s Diet Beliefs

replies.comment info:

Unfortunately, the original data is not readily available.  Some of it is given in the New York Times article that included this graph.  Return on Friday, when we will reveal the free link to the article.  You can estimate the other statistics from the graph.

name: Jostyn
comment info:
I notice on this scatter plot graph of nutritionists and the American peoples rating of various foods.  As expected, things like pizza, soda, ice cream and french fries were unanimously considered unhealthy by people of both spheres.  Though there is some disparity among other foods.  For example, 80% of Americans believe Granola is healthy, while only around 45% of nutritionists believe it, and so on with other foods, like coconut oil, frozen yogurt, and granola bars.  But even so, there doesn’t seem to be a wide or substantial difference between what Americans believe is healthy and what nutritionists believe is healthy, as we can see a very positive trend line, or line of best fit.


I wonder what is considered “healthy”.  I also wonder whether the sample sizes of the survey (2,000 people and 672 nutritionists)  is a valid representation or census of what each party thinks. 


This relates to me and my community because it directly reflects what the general public  in the U.S  and I were taught growing up regarding which foods are considered healthy.  Evidently, many of us were being informed about what foods are healthy and unhealthy in a way very similar to the nutritionist’s views.


“The people vs the nutritionists: Surprisingly unanimous.”

replies.name: D
replies.comment info: I also wonder if the amount of nutritionist and American public people surveyed also affected the results!

name: Jostyn
comment info:

As expected, things like pizza, soda, ice cream and french fries were unanimously considered unhealthy by people of both spheres.  Though there is some disparity among other foods. But even so, there doesn’t seem to be a wide or substantial difference between what Americans believe is healthy and what nutritionists believe is healthy, as we can see a very positive trend line, or line of best fit.


I wonder what is considered “healthy”.  I also wonder whether the sample sizes of the survey (2,000 people and 672 nutritionists)  is a valid representation or census of what each party thinks. 


This relates to me and my community because it directly reflects what the general public  in the U.S  and I were taught growing up regarding which foods are considered healthy.  Evidently, many of us were being informed about what foods are healthy and unhealthy in a way very similar to the nutritionist’s views.

“The people vs the nutritionists: Surprisingly unanimous.”

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Jostyn--

So many great noticings and wonderings here.  Just a few stat terms to clear up.  (Note:  There are Stat Nuggets for these at the end of the Reveal and Stat Nugget index.)
Line of best fit AKA LSRL (least squares regressions line) is the line, as you say, goes through the middle of the graph.  It has coordinates that "best" guess what the nutritionists percentage is given the public's percentage.  But, alas, The line in this graph is not a line of best fit.  It's something else.  (Hint:  Pick a few points on the line and draw a horizontal line to the y-axis and a vertical line to the x-axis.  What do you notice about the coordinates?  This makes the line the ... -- something that you learned in algebra, not statistics, awhile ago.)

Regarding sample size, you are asking the right questions!  About 1,000 respondents is sufficient IF the sample is random and representative of the population.  (There’s a lot of math behind why the number is 1,000.)  The public’s sample could be large enough, if it is representative.  The nutritionist’s sample size of 672 could be large enough if it is representative and meets some other conditions.
